title: 114_s1871
content: The "Medicare Common Access Card Act of 2015" establishes a Secure Medicare Card Pilot Program. The "Medicare Common Access Card Act of 2015" establishes a pilot program under title XVIII of the Social Security Act to utilize smart card technology for Medicare beneficiary identification cards. The program aims to improve care quality, billing accuracy, reduce identity theft, and combat waste, fraud, and abuse in the Medicare program. The Secretary will conduct a pilot program in high-risk areas to provide smart card Medicare identification cards to beneficiaries who have had their personal information compromised. The pilot program will issue smart cards to Medicare beneficiaries with secure personal information storage for verification, fraud prevention, and transaction authorization. The Secretary will monitor and review the program regularly. The pilot program includes regular monitoring by the Secretary of Medicare providers' billings and beneficiaries' records to address inaccurate charges, waste, fraud, or abuse. Reporting mechanisms will measure cost savings to the Medicare program. Provisions ensure compliance with identity credential standards. The pilot program includes monitoring by the Secretary of Medicare providers' billings and beneficiaries' records to address inaccurate charges, waste, fraud, or abuse. Requirements include two-factor authentication to protect Medicare beneficiary information and guidelines for verifying identity and eligibility for services. The pilot program ensures Medicare beneficiaries are informed about the program's purpose, eligibility processes, and data protection measures. It also addresses issues related to equipment loss or damage. The pilot program for Medicare beneficiaries includes provisions for equipment, a hotline for assistance, and addressing care access issues. Information on the smart card can only be disclosed as permitted by federal privacy regulations. The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 exempts smart card information from disclosure. The Secretary has the authority to expand the pilot program and waive certain provisions of the Social Security Act. A report to Congress detailing the program's design is required within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 2 years of implementing the pilot program, detailing issues related to expansion, recommendations for legislation, and justifications for nationwide implementation. In this section, definitions are provided for terms like "Medicare beneficiary," "Medicare program," "Medicare provider," and "pilot program." These definitions clarify the terms used in the context of the pilot program conducted under this section. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and "smart card" is defined as a secure electronic card with an embedded chip.
